title.narrative: Practical application of participatory innovation development for improving food and nutrition security among poor farming communities

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
The key capacity need that the requesting organisation expressed in the proposal was the lack of skills, knowledge and attitude of staff in NGOs, CBOs and government agencies to recognise the creativity of smallholder farmers to engage with farmer innovators in farmer-led innovation development processes. The TMT was entirely geared to fill this capacity need - not only theoretically through the on-line workshops, but also practically through the pilot projects that the trainees engaged in. Despite the challenges faced due to Covid restrictions, the TMT effectively and efficiently met its objective of training and mentoring a group of participants from 11 organisations in participatory innovation development. We were able to cover the content, engage the trainees in field application of what they had learned, reflected on the learning at the final workshop, and stayed within budget. Moreover, through the field pilots, we were able to provide an opportunity for trainees to work in multistakeholder groups, which was a new and useful experience for them.
**Lessons and recommendations:**
a. Unforeseen circumstances (such as the Covid pandemic) called for adaptability, flexibility and patience from all involved. A good team (trainers, field facilitator and requesting organisation) that was able to communicate and make necessary changes helped to successfully complete and achieve the objectives of the TMT. The support and understanding from the side of Nuffic were equally important.
b. Virtual training became the only way forward in the face of the Covid pandemic. However, it is quite a challenge in countries (areas) that do not have good connectivity and participants who have limited or no connectivity. In such situations, it is essential to have a competent and capable field facilitator on location for organisation, logistics etc.
c. Enabling the participation of women was sought from the outset of the programme and we were diligent in following this through. We thus succeeded in getting women trainees who participated actively throughout the programme. Moreover, a mix of men and women participants allowed for good discussions on gender issues and how it relates to their work as development practitioners.
d. The use of "real life" cases of farmer innovation from across Africa in the training was considered illuminating by the trainees. They were motivated to seek farmer innovation within their own fields of work.
e. The short field pilots were an excellent way for the trainees to apply what they had learnt hands-on and in collaborative teams. Though short, these pilots were greatly appreciated by the trainees. Moreover, they were able to share their experiences through the reflection workshops. The trainees will continue the activities started through these field pilots even after the completion of the TMT.
f. The trainees will continue to be connected through the Prolinnova country network as well as with network partners in other African countries and thereby continue to share and learn together on farmer-led innovation. This is important in terms of sustainability.
​
​

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
**Output 1: 18 staff members from Kulima and other agricultural development organisations attend the two TMT training workshops and prepare action plans.**
Despite the Covid-19 related challenges, this output was achieved with satisfaction. 15 staff members of 11 organisations including Kulima (as requesting organisation) attended the two workshops. The main activities completed in relation to this output were:
- Introductory (virtual) training workshop in local innovation and participatory innovation development (14 to 17 September 2020) - Preparation of post-training pilot projects by trainees in four groups based on a farmer innovation within their working areas. Four PID pilots were submitted to their managers and the trainers and approved for implementation. - Implementation of the pilots projects during a period of 5-6 months, involving the farming community, other staff from their own and other organisations (From October 2020 to March 2021) - Monitoring of the pilots and mentoring of the trainees by the local facilitator, on-site, and the trainers, virtually. - Reflection workshop at the end of the programme with each pilot project group presenting their findings, what they had learned and how they plan to share their knowledge with their colleagues (26 - 28 April 2021).
**Output 2: 18 development practitioners develop practical skills in identifying examples of local innovation and supporting their improvement through a process of PID**
This output was also achieved with success through the pilot projects undertaken by the trainees. These pilots were based on local innovations identified by the trainees in their working areas:
Pilot 1 - ++Use of mint as a biopesticide++ (an innovation of a male farmer innovator). This pilot was used to set up and implement a joint experiment to try out the mint decoction against aphids with a larger group of small-scale farmers on their cabbage plots. The community members, mostly women, planted cabbage on four plots and were able to get a good harvest with no attacks from aphids using mint as a biopesticide. (trainees from UCAM/UNAC engaged in this pilot)
Pilot 2 - ++Use of pots made of banana yarn (biodegradable material) for raising plant/tree nurseries instead of plastic bags++ in Gwemulini, Chiboto District. This is an innovation of a woman farmer. In this pilot, the trainees joined up with the innovator to share the innovation within the community. The woman innovator taught the others how to make the banana yarn pots, they then made their own and raised plant nurseries. The seedlings were planted in areas that have been damaged due to erosion caused by heavy rain and flooding in the area. 23 community members learned about the innovation. They made 500 degradable pots, raised 500 seedlings (mainly fruit trees), and planted them on degraded land during the pilot. The produce of the trees will be for family consumption of the community. They also set up a community nursery (trainees from Tchemulane Association, FONGA, and ACTIVA were engaged in this pilot).
Pilot 3 - ++Drying of tomatoes and other vegetables to combat post-harvest loss and increase shelf life++ in Conhane, Chokwe district. Traditionally, vegetables are boiled for preservation. This innovation of a women farmer has used drying instead. Her method was shared and tried out successfully by 60 women farmers who now have a better way to preserve their vegetables (trainees from ISPG, ARES, and Kulima engaged in this pilot).
Pilot 4 - ++Protecting vegetable plots against saltwater intrusion by placing pipes in the dyke++. This is an innovation by a farmer who managed to keep out the saltwater from his vegetable plot of 2 ha by placing pipes in the dyke in the coastal area of Marrambone, Inhambane. Through this pilot, the trainees were able to share the innovation with farmers in the larger community and expand the technique to reclaim 33 ha and use the land to grow vegetables. (trainees from ACUDES, DPP, and UPCI were involved in this pilot)

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 15-12-2021: As this was a one-year TMT, the opportunity for initial application of the acquired knowledge was provided through the pilot projects that were undertaken by the trainees after the first training workshop. These pilots were of 5-6 month duration. The trainees formed themselves into four groups (based on geographical proximity) and undertook a collaborative pilot based on a local farmer innovation from their working environment. They shared the tasks within the pilots based on their own specialisations.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 15-12-2021: In addition to this group who participated in the training programme, colleagues from their organisations got involved in sharing through the post-training pilot projects. Thus knowledge was shared with a larger number of people who could not be accommodated in the training programme itself.

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 15-12-2021: More women than men were involved in this training programme and participated actively.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 15-12-2021: The subject matter (farmer innovation, participatory innovation development, multistakeholder collaboration etc.) covered in this training was new to most of the participants. In addition, the methods used for training, which focused on adult learning and hands-on application of new knowledge/skills was appreciated by the participants. After the initial training workshop, all trainees engaged in short pilot projects in which they applied what was learnt and this helped them to internalise the new knowledge/skills.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: The core of this training programme was to get trainees acquainted with the participatory innovation development (PID) approach for improving food and nutrition security. This approach takes farmer innovation as an entry point. As such, emphasis was placed on the need to discover and support innovation of women farmers, which is often hidden from sight. Gender integration into PID was covered as one of the sessions in the training. There was a good gender balance among the trainees which allowed for getting the feedback of both men and women and examining the need to give more attention to women farmers who are often disadvantaged. The trainees were also encouraged to look for women's innovation in their post-training pilots. This exposure to gender in a very practical way helped the trainees to better understand the need to pursue gender equality and equity in their daily work as agricultural and development workers.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
This training programme has contributed to changing attitudes of trainees in the following aspects:
a. **Recognising and respecting farmer innovation **- realising that small-scale farmers are people who are knowledgeable and experienced in food production and capable of finding new and innovative ways of improving their farming. Hence, identifying and supporting these farmer innovations and sharing them with others can help in improving food and nutrition security in small-scale farmer communities.
b. **Collaboration with others in development** - Often staff in organisations are rather insular in their activities. This training has shown them the importance and value of multi-stakeholder collaboration and how it can be more efficient in pooling strengths and resources and reducing duplication. The trainees came from different organisations and were able to interact and work with each other in the training as well as in the pilot projects.
c. **The role of facilitation** - often, staff of development organisations (public and private) tend to take the lead and make decisions on behalf of farming communities. However, this training has emphasised the need to play a facilitating/ supporting role, giving community members (women and men) the opportunity to make their own development decisions.
